\doxysubsection{Detailed Description}
Base class for socket objects. 

This class wraps an OS socket handle and maintains strict ownership semantics. If a socket object has a valid, open socket, then it owns the handle and will close it when the object is destroyed.

Objects of this class are not copyable, but they are moveable.

{\em addr} & The address to which we get bound. \\
\hline
{\em reuse} & A reuse option for the socket. This can be SO\+\_\+\+REUSE\+\_\+\+ADDR or SO\+\_\+\+REUSEPORT, and is set before it tries to bind. A value of zero doesn;t set an option. \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyReturn}{Returns}
{\itshape true} on success, {\itshape false} on error 
\end{DoxyReturn}

\Hypertarget{classsockpp_1_1socket_a507166efe9e8a561b05f33ceb38fb6c2}\index{sockpp::socket@{sockpp::socket}!clone@{clone}}
\index{clone@{clone}!sockpp::socket@{sockpp::socket}}
\doxysubsubsection{\texorpdfstring{clone()}{clone()}}
{\footnotesize\ttfamily \label{classsockpp_1_1socket_a507166efe9e8a561b05f33ceb38fb6c2} 
\mbox{\hyperlink{classsockpp_1_1socket}{socket}} sockpp\+::socket\+::clone (\begin{DoxyParamCaption}{}{}\end{DoxyParamCaption}) const}



Creates a new socket that refers to this one. 

This creates a new object with an independent lifetime, but refers back to this same socket. On most systems, this duplicates the file handle using the dup() call. A typical use of this is to have separate threads for reading and writing the socket. One thread would get the original socket and the other would get the cloned one. \begin{DoxyReturn}{Returns}
A new socket object that refers to the same socket as this one. 
\end{DoxyReturn}
\Hypertarget{classsockpp_1_1socket_a7cedbbe99379cce20bfd12ee59fd3880}\index{sockpp::socket@{sockpp::socket}!close@{close}}
\index{close@{close}!sockpp::socket@{sockpp::socket}}
\doxysubsubsection{\texorpdfstring{close()}{close()}}
{\footnotesize\ttfamily \label{classsockpp_1_1socket_a7cedbbe99379cce20bfd12ee59fd3880} 
virtual \mbox{\hyperlink{classsockpp_1_1result}{result}} sockpp\+::socket\+::close (\begin{DoxyParamCaption}{}{}\end{DoxyParamCaption})\hspace{0.3cm}{\ttfamily [virtual]}}



Closes the socket. 

After closing the socket, the handle is {\itshape invalid}, and can not be used again until reassigned. \begin{DoxyReturn}{Returns}
{\itshape true} if the sock is closed, {\itshape false} on error. 
\end{DoxyReturn}
\Hypertarget{classsockpp_1_1socket_ab68eb87fa97b0978b104b9f5b97275bc}\index{sockpp::socket@{sockpp::socket}!create@{create}}
\index{create@{create}!sockpp::socket@{sockpp::socket}}
\doxysubsubsection{\texorpdfstring{create()}{create()}}
{\footnotesize\ttfamily \label{classsockpp_1_1socket_ab68eb87fa97b0978b104b9f5b97275bc} 
static \mbox{\hyperlink{classsockpp_1_1result}{result}}$<$ \mbox{\hyperlink{classsockpp_1_1socket}{socket}} $>$ sockpp\+::socket\+::create (\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{int}]{domain}{, }\item[{int}]{type}{, }\item[{int}]{protocol}{ = {\ttfamily 0}}\end{DoxyParamCaption})\hspace{0.3cm}{\ttfamily [static]}, {\ttfamily [noexcept]}}



Creates a socket with the specified communications characterics. 

Not that this is not normally how a socket is creates in the sockpp library. Applications would typically create a connector (client) or acceptor (server) socket which would take care of the details.

This is included for completeness or for creating different types of sockets than are supported by the library.


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em domain} & The communications domain for the sockets (i.\+e. the address family) \\
\hline
{\em type} & The communication semantics for the sockets (SOCK\+\_\+\+STREAM, SOCK\+\_\+\+DGRAM, etc). \\
\hline
{\em protocol} & The particular protocol to be used with the sockets\\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyReturn}{Returns}
A socket with the requested communications characteristics. 
\end{DoxyReturn}

\Hypertarget{classsockpp_1_1socket_a3700aaee7cf34bf0bc50925a5b6f24fe}\index{sockpp::socket@{sockpp::socket}!pair@{pair}}
\index{pair@{pair}!sockpp::socket@{sockpp::socket}}
\doxysubsubsection{\texorpdfstring{pair()}{pair()}}
{\footnotesize\ttfamily \label{classsockpp_1_1socket_a3700aaee7cf34bf0bc50925a5b6f24fe} 
static \mbox{\hyperlink{classsockpp_1_1result}{result}}$<$ \mbox{\hyperlink{classsockpp_1_1socket_a342a6a36c1137d64da6da1dcefe0f07c}{socket\+\_\+pair}} $>$ sockpp\+::socket\+::pair (\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{int}]{domain}{, }\item[{int}]{type}{, }\item[{int}]{protocol}{ = {\ttfamily 0}}\end{DoxyParamCaption})\hspace{0.3cm}{\ttfamily [static]}, {\ttfamily [noexcept]}}



Creates a pair of connected sockets. 

Whether this will work at all is highly system and domain dependent. Currently it is only known to work for Unix-\/domain sockets on \texorpdfstring{$\ast$}{*}nix systems.

Note that applications would normally call this from a derived socket class which would return the properly type-\/cast sockets to match the {\ttfamily domain} and {\ttfamily type}.


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em domain} & The communications domain for the sockets (i.\+e. the address family) \\
\hline
{\em type} & The communication semantics for the sockets (SOCK\+\_\+\+STREAM, SOCK\+\_\+\+DGRAM, etc). \\
\hline
{\em protocol} & The particular protocol to be used with the sockets\\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyReturn}{Returns}
A pair (std\+::tuple) of sockets on success, or an error code on failure. 
\end{DoxyReturn}

{\footnotesize\ttfamily \label{classsockpp_1_1socket_a38c57915c60f8dd14ad50f24a3de659f} 
virtual \mbox{\hyperlink{classsockpp_1_1result}{result}} sockpp\+::socket\+::set\+\_\+non\+\_\+blocking (\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{bool}]{on}{ = {\ttfamily true}}\end{DoxyParamCaption})\hspace{0.3cm}{\ttfamily [virtual]}}



Places the socket into or out of non-\/blocking mode. 

When in non-\/blocking mode, a call that is not immediately ready to complete (read, write, accept, etc) will return immediately with the error EWOULDBLOCK. 
\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em on} & Whether to turn non-\/blocking mode on or off. \\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}

{\itshape true} on success, {\itshape false} on failure.

{\footnotesize\ttfamily \label{classsockpp_1_1socket_a04d3ecb84c73ffee39156707ba06a13a} 
\mbox{\hyperlink{classsockpp_1_1result}{result}} sockpp\+::socket\+::shutdown (\begin{DoxyParamCaption}\item[{int}]{how}{ = {\ttfamily SHUT\+\_\+RDWR}}\end{DoxyParamCaption})}



Shuts down all or part of the full-\/duplex connection. 


\begin{DoxyParams}{Parameters}
{\em how} & Which part of the connection should be shut\+: \begin{DoxyItemize}
\item SHUT\+\_\+\+RD (0) Further reads disallowed. \item SHUT\+\_\+\+WR (1) Further writes disallowed \item SHUT\+\_\+\+RDWR (2) Further reads and writes disallowed. \end{DoxyItemize}
\\
\hline
\end{DoxyParams}
\begin{DoxyReturn}{Returns}
{\itshape true} on success, {\itshape false} on error. 
\end{DoxyReturn}
